member.name: M:Sharpmake.Assembler.CleanupTmpAssemblies
member.summary: This method is intended to be called at executable init time. It let us avoid exceptions when executing sharpmake several times in loops(exception can occur in the cs compiler when it tries to create pdb files and some already exists. Maybe that previous sharpmake sometimes still has some handles to the file?). With this cleanup code active there is no exception anymore on my PC. Previously I had the exception almost 100% on the second or third iteration of a stability test(executing sharpmake in loop to insure it always generate the same thing).
member.remarks: Was previously having the following exception when running stability tests(on subsequents sharpmake execution runs): Unexpected error creating debug information file 'c:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Temp\Sharpmake.Assembler_1.tmp.PDB' -- 'c:\Users\xxxx\AppData\Local\Temp\Sharpmake.Assembler_1.tmp.pdb: The process cannot access the file because it is being used by another process.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.ConfigurePriority
member.summary:
This method attribute is used to specify the execution order of Configure(...) within a project or a solution generation
If this attribute is not set a default value a 0 is used
The configure methods using this property are sorted ascendingly. ex: ... -1 before 0 before 1 ...
See Configure method attribute and Configurable class for more details

member.name: T:Sharpmake.CompositeFragmentAttribute
member.summary: Marks elements of fragments that should not be considered individual fragments.
member.remarks: When an enumeration is marked with , Sharpmake normally ensure that each element sets 1 and only 1 bit. However, it is often useful in a bit enum to combine multiple bits together to create sets that go well together. To prevent Sharpmake from considering those errors, you must decorate these enum members with .

member.name: T:Sharpmake.ExtensionLoader
member.summary: Helper for loading Sharpmake extensions.
member.remarks: Normally, this should be done using reflection-only load, but the problem is that you have to resolve the dependencies yourself. Turns out that it's simpler to actually let the CLR do a full load in a temporary that we can trash later.

member.summary: Gets whether an assembly is a Sharpmake extension.
member.param: The path of the assembly to check whether it's an extension.
member.returns: `true` if it is an extension, `false` otherwise.
member.remarks: This method will instantiate a remote if none was created.

member.name: M:Sharpmake.ExtensionLoader.LoadExtension(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads a Sharpmake extension assembly.
member.param: The path of the assembly that contains the Sharpmake extension.
Whether this method should load the assembly remotely first. See remarks.
member.returns: The loaded extension's .
member.remarks: Because loading an extension in a remote assembly for validation is expensive, this method provides the argument which, when `false`, will load the extension in the current instead of doing so in a remote , testing whether it contains , and then loading it again in . However, because it is impossible to unload a loaded assembly from the CLR, if this method fail you have essentially polluted the process' address space with an assembly that you may not need.

member.param: The path to the directory to scan for assemblies.
member.returns: A that contains the loaded .

member.name: P:Sharpmake.Util.VsInstallation.ProductID
member.summary: The full list of products can be found here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-and-component-ids

member.name: P:Sharpmake.Util.VsInstallation.Workloads
member.summary:
This can be used to check and limit by specific installed workloads.
What is a Workload? In the VS installer, a 'Workload' is a section that you see in the UI such as 'Desktop development with C++' or '.NET desktop development'.
The full list of products is here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-and-component-ids
For each product, clicking it will bring up a page of all of the possible Workloads. For example: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-component-id-vs-professional

member.name: P:Sharpmake.Util.VsInstallation.Components
member.summary:
This can be used to check and limit by specific installed components. What is a Component? In the Visual Studio Installer, the 'Components' are individual components associated with each Workload (and some just on the side), that you can see in the Summary on the right. Each workflow contains a number of mandatory components, but also a list of optional ones. An example would be: 'NuGet package manager' or 'C++/CLI support'.
The full list of products is here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-and-component-ids
For each product, clicking it will bring up a page of all of the possible Workloads. For example: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-component-id-vs-professional

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Util.s_supportedVisualStudioProducts
member.summary:
The supported visual studio products, in order by priority in which Sharpmake will choose them. We want to block products like the standalone Team Explorer, which is in the Visual Studio family yet isn't a variant of Visual Studio proper.
The list of Product IDs can be found here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/workload-and-component-ids

member.name: F:Sharpmake.FastBuildSettings.SetPathToResourceCompilerInEnvironment
member.summary:
link.exe on win64 executes rc.exe by itself on some occasions if it doesn't find it, link errors can occur, like: fatal error LNK1158: cannot run rc.exe!
Setting this to true will have sharpmake detect if a rc.exe can be found in the same folder as link.exe, and if not add the path to one in the global settings Environment section, in the PATH variable

member.summary: Verbosity of the tasks (vcxproj only) At the time of this writing, this only control if on build env variables values are printed

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.CSharp.SuppressWarning
member.summary: Suppressed specific warnings in a C# project.
member.remarks: This option generates a `NoWarn` element in the C# project XML.

member.name: M:Sharpmake.Options.CSharp.SuppressWarning.#ctor(System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance from a list of warning code labels.
member.param: The list of warning code labels to suppress. See remarks.
member.remarks: If contains elements that are not C# compiler warnings, those warning numbers *must* include the 2-letter prefix. For example, NuGet warnings must be prefixed by `NU`. (ie: `NU1603`)

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.CSharp.WarningsNotAsErrors
member.summary: Prevent specific warnings from being treated as errors when is enabled
member.remarks: This option generates a `WarningsNotAsErrors` element in the C# project XML.

member.name: M:Sharpmake.Options.CSharp.WarningsNotAsErrors.#ctor(System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance from a list of warning code labels.
member.param: The list of warning code labels to avoid treating as errors. See remarks.
member.remarks: If contains elements that are not C# compiler warnings, those warning numbers *must* include the 2-letter prefix. For example, NuGet warnings must be prefixed by `NU`. (ie: `NU1603`)

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.CSharp.SonarQubeExclude
member.summary: Exclude from SonarQube C# static analysis

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.CSharp.IsPublishable
member.summary: Controls whether the project is published when running a publish command Only affects processes that use the Publish target, such as the dotnet sdk projects

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.PlatformToolset

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.TranslateIncludes
member.summary: Translate Includes to Imports
member.remarks: Enables the compiler to translate #include directives into import directives for the available header units. (/translateInclude)

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.CharacterSet
member.summary: Character Set
member.remarks: Tells the compiler to use the specified character set; aids in localization issues.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.CharacterSet.Default
member.summary: Not Set

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.CharacterSet.Unicode
member.summary: Use Unicode Character Set

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.CharacterSet.MultiByte
member.summary: Use Multi-Byte Character Set

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WholeProgramOptimization
member.summary: Whole Program Optimization
member.remarks: Enables cross-module optimizations by delaying code generation to link time; requires that linker option 'Link Time Code Generation' be turned on.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WholeProgramOptimization.Disable
member.summary: No Whole Program Optimization

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WholeProgramOptimization.LinkTime
member.summary: Use Link Time Code Generation

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WholeProgramOptimization.Instrument
member.summary: Profile Guided Optimization - Instrument

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WholeProgramOptimization.Optimize
member.summary: Profile Guided Optimization - Optimize

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.DebugInformation
member.summary: Debug Information Format
member.remarks: Specifies the type of debugging information generated by the compiler. This requires compatible linker settings.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.DebugInformation.Disable
member.summary: None
member.remarks: Produces no debugging information, so compilation may be faster.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.DebugInformation.C7Compatible
member.summary: C7 compatible
member.remarks: Select the type of debugging information created for your program and whether this information is kept in object (.obj) files or in a program database (PDB).

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.DebugInformation.ProgramDatabase
member.summary: Program Database
member.remarks: Produces a program database (PDB) that contains type information and symbolic debugging information for use with the debugger. The symbolic debugging information includes the names and types of variables, as well as functions and line numbers.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.DebugInformation.ProgramDatabaseEnC
member.summary: Program Database for Edit And Continue
member.remarks: Produces a program database, as described above, in a format that supports the Edit and Continue feature.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.UseDebugLibraries
member.summary: Use Debug Libraries
member.remarks: Specifies whether this configuration should use debug libraries and debug switches

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WarningLevel
member.summary: Warning Level
member.remarks: Select how strict you want the compiler to be about code errors.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WarningLevel.Level0
member.summary: Turn Off All Warnings
member.remarks: Level 0 disables all warnings.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WarningLevel.Level1
member.summary: Level 1 displays severe warnings. Level 1 is the default warning level at the command line.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WarningLevel.Level2
member.summary: Level 2 displays all level 1 warnings and warnings less severe than level 1.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WarningLevel.Level3
member.summary: Level 3 displays all level 2 warnings and all other warnings recommended for production purposes.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WarningLevel.Level4
member.summary: Level 4 displays all level 3 warnings plus informational warnings, which in most cases can be safely ignored.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.WarningLevel.EnableAllWarnings
member.summary: Enables all warnings, including those disabled by default.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.TreatWarningsAsErrors
member.summary: Treat Warnings As Errors
member.remarks: Treats all compiler warnings as errors. For a new project, it may be best to use /WX in all compilations; resolving all warnings will ensure the fewest possible hard-to-find code defects.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.DiagnosticsFormat
member.summary: Diagnostics Format
member.remarks: Enables rich diagnostics, with column information and source context in diagnostic messages.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.DiagnosticsFormat.Caret
member.summary: Provides column information in the diagnostic message, as well as outputting the relevant line of source code with a caret indicating the offending column.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.DiagnosticsFormat.ColumnInfo
member.summary: Additionally provides the column number within the line where the diagnostic is issued, where applicable.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.DiagnosticsFormat.Classic
member.summary: Retains the prior, concise diagnostic messages with the line number.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.TreatAngleIncludeAsExternal
member.summary: Treat Files Included with Angle Brackets as External
member.remarks: Specifies whether to treat files included with angle brackets as external. (/external:anglebrackets)

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.ExternalWarningLevel
member.summary: External Header Warning Level
member.remarks: Select how strict you want the compiler to be about code errors in external headers. (/external:W0 - /external:W4)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.ExternalWarningLevel.Level0
member.summary: Turn Off All Warnings
member.remarks: Level 0 disables all warnings.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.ExternalWarningLevel.Level1
member.summary: Level 1 displays severe warnings. Level 1 is the default warning level at the command line.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.ExternalWarningLevel.Level2
member.summary: Level 2 displays all level 1 warnings and warnings less severe than level 1.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.ExternalWarningLevel.Level3
member.summary: Level 3 displays all level 2 warnings and all other warnings recommended for production purposes.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.ExternalWarningLevel.Level4
member.summary: Level 4 displays all level 3 warnings plus informational warnings, which in most cases can be safely ignored.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.ExternalWarningLevel.InheritWarningLevel
member.summary: Inherit Project Warning Level

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.ExternalTemplatesDiagnostics
member.summary: Template Diagnostics in External Headers
member.remarks: Specifies whether to evaluate warning level across template instantiation chain. (/external:templates-)

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.EnableManagedIncrementalBuild
member.summary: Enable Managed Incremental Build
member.remarks: Enables managed incremental build scenarios using metagen.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.CommonLanguageRuntimeSupport
member.summary: Common Language RunTime Support
member.remarks: Use the .NET runtime service. This switch is incompatible with some other switches; see the documentation on the /clr family of switches for details.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.CommonLanguageRuntimeSupport.NoClrSupport
member.summary: No Common Language RunTime Support

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.CommonLanguageRuntimeSupport.ClrSupport
member.summary: Common Language RunTime Support
member.remarks: Creates metadata for your application that can be consumed by other CLR applications, and allows your application to consume types and data in the metadata of other CLR components.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.CommonLanguageRuntimeSupport.PureMsilClrSupport
member.summary: Pure MSIL Common Language RunTime Support
member.remarks: Produces an MSIL-only output file with no native executable code, although it can contain native types compiled to MSIL.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.General.CommonLanguageRuntimeSupport.SafeMsilClrSupport
member.summary: Safe MSIL Common Language RunTime Support
member.remarks: Produces an MSIL-only (no native executable code) and verifiable output file.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.MultiProcessorCompilation
member.summary: Multi-processor Compilation

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Optimization
member.summary: Select option for code optimization; choose Custom to use specific optimization options.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Optimization.Disable
member.summary: Disable optimization.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Optimization.MinimizeSize
member.summary: Maximum Optimization (Favor Size)
member.remarks: Equivalent to /Og /Os /Oy /Ob2 /Gs /GF /Gy

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Optimization.MaximizeSpeed
member.summary: Maximum Optimization (Favor Speed)
member.remarks: Equivalent to /Og /Oi /Ot /Oy /Ob2 /Gs /GF /Gy

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Optimization.FullOptimization
member.summary: Optimizations (Favor Speed)
member.remarks: Equivalent to /Og /Oi /Ot /Oy /Ob2

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Inline
member.summary: Inline Function Expansion
member.remarks: Select the level of inline function expansion for the build.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Inline.OnlyInline
member.summary: Only __inline
member.remarks: Expands only functions marked as inline, __inline, __forceinline or __inline or, in a C++ member function, defined within a class declaration.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Inline.AnySuitable
member.summary: Any Suitable
member.remarks: Expands functions marked as inline or __inline and any other function that the compiler chooses (expansion occurs at the compiler's discretion, often referred to as auto-inlining).

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Inline.Disable
member.summary: Disables inline expansion, which is on by default.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Intrinsic
member.summary: Enable Intrinsic Functions
member.remarks: Using intrinsic functions generates faster, but possibly larger, code.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FavorSizeOrSpeed
member.summary: Favor Size Or Speed
member.remarks: Whether to favor code size or code speed; 'Global Optimization' must be turned on.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FavorSizeOrSpeed.Neither
member.summary: No size nor speed optimization.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FavorSizeOrSpeed.FastCode
member.summary: Favor Fast Code. Maximizes the speed of EXEs and DLLs by instructing the compiler to favor speed over size. (This is the default.)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FavorSizeOrSpeed.SmallCode
member.summary: Favor Small Code. Minimizes the size of EXEs and DLLs by instructing the compiler to favor size over speed.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.OmitFramePointers
member.summary: Omit Frame Pointers
member.remarks: Suppresses creation of frame pointers on the call stack.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FiberSafe
member.summary: Enable Fiber-Safe Optimizations
member.remarks: Enables memory space optimization when using fibers and thread local storage access.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.IgnoreStandardIncludePath
member.summary: Ignore Standard Include Paths
member.remarks: Prevents the compiler from searching for include files in directories specified in the INCLUDE environment variables.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.GenerateProcessorFile
member.summary: Preprocess to a File
member.remarks: Preprocesses C and C++ source files and writes the preprocessed output to a file. This option suppresses compilation, thus it does not produce an .obj file.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.GenerateProcessorFile.WithoutLineNumbers
member.summary: Preprocess without #line directives.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.KeepComment
member.summary: Suppresses comment strip from source code; requires that one of the 'Preprocessing' options be set.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.StringPooling
member.summary: Enables the compiler to create a single read-only copy of identical strings in the program image and in memory during execution, resulting in smaller programs, an optimization called string pooling. /O1, /O2, and /ZI automatically set /GF option.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.MinimalRebuild
member.summary: Enables minimal rebuild, which determines whether C++ source files that include changed C++ class definitions (stored in header (.h) files) need to be recompiled.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Exceptions
member.summary: Enable C++ Exceptions
member.remarks: Specifies the model of exception handling to be used by the compiler.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Exceptions.Disable
member.summary: No exception handling.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Exceptions.Enable
member.summary: The exception-handling model that catches C++ exceptions only and tells the compiler to assume that extern C functions never throw a C++ exception. (/EHsc)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Exceptions.EnableWithExternC
member.summary: The exception-handling model that catches C++ exceptions only and tells the compiler to assume that extern C functions do throw an exception. (/EHs)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.Exceptions.EnableWithSEH
member.summary: The exception-handling model that catches asynchronous (structured) and synchronous (C++) exceptions. (/EHa)

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.TypeChecks
member.summary: Smaller Type Check
member.remarks: Enable checking for conversion to smaller types, incompatible with any optimization type other than debug.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RuntimeChecks
member.summary: Perform basic runtime error checks, incompatible with any optimization type other than debug.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RuntimeChecks.StackFrames
member.summary: Enables stack frame run-time error checking.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RuntimeChecks.UninitializedVariables
member.summary: Reports when a variable is used without having been initialized.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RuntimeChecks.Both
member.summary: Both (/RTC1, equiv. to /RTCsu)

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RuntimeLibrary
member.summary: Specify runtime library for linking.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RuntimeLibrary.MultiThreaded
member.summary: Multi-threaded
member.remarks: Causes your application to use the multithread, static version of the run-time library.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RuntimeLibrary.MultiThreadedDebug
member.summary: Multi-threaded Debug
member.remarks: Defines _DEBUG and _MT. This option also causes the compiler to place the library name LIBCMTD.lib into the .obj file so that the linker will use LIBCMTD.lib to resolve external symbols.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RuntimeLibrary.MultiThreadedDLL
member.summary: Multi-threaded DLL
member.remarks: Causes your application to use the multithread- and DLL-specific version of the run-time library. Defines _MT and _DLL and causes the compiler to place the library name MSVCRT.lib into the .obj file.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RuntimeLibrary.MultiThreadedDebugDLL
member.summary: Multi-threaded Debug DLL
member.remarks: Defines _DEBUG, _MT, and _DLL and causes your application to use the debug multithread- and DLL-specific version of the run-time library. It also causes the compiler to place the library name MSVCRTD.lib into the .obj file.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.StructAlignment
member.summary: Struct Member Alignment
member.remarks: Specifies 1, 2, 4, or 8-byte boundaries for struct member alignment.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.StructAlignment.Default
member.summary: Default alignment settings.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.StructAlignment.Alignment1
member.summary: 1 Byte
member.remarks: Packs structures on 1-byte boundaries. Same as /Zp.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.StructAlignment.Alignment2
member.summary: 2 Bytes
member.remarks: Packs structures on 2-byte boundaries.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.StructAlignment.Alignment4
member.summary: 4 Byte
member.remarks: Packs structures on 4-byte boundaries.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.StructAlignment.Alignment8
member.summary: 8 Bytes
member.remarks: Packs structures on 8-byte boundaries (default).

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.StructAlignment.Alignment16
member.summary: 16 Bytes
member.remarks: Packs structures on 16-byte boundaries.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.BufferSecurityCheck
member.summary: Security Check
member.remarks: The Security Check helps detect stack-buffer over-runs, a common attempted attack upon a program's security.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.BufferSecurityCheck.Disable
member.summary: Disable Security Check. (/GS-)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.BufferSecurityCheck.Enable
member.summary: Enable Security Check. (/GS)

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FunctionLevelLinking
member.summary: Enable Function-Level Linking
member.remarks: Allows the compiler to package individual functions in the form of packaged functions (COMDATs). Required for edit and continue to work.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.EnhancedInstructionSet
member.summary: Enable Enhanced Instruction Set
member.remarks: Enable use of instructions found on processors that support enhanced instruction sets, e.g., the SSE, SSE2, AVX, AVX2 and AVX-512 enhancements to IA-32; AVX, AVX2 and AVX-512 to x64. Currently /arch:SSE and /arch:SSE2 are only available when building for the x86 architecture. If no option is specified, the compiler will use instructions found on processors that support SSE2. Use of enhanced instructions can be disabled with /arch:IA32. (/arch:SSE, /arch:SSE2, /arch:AVX, /arch:AVX2, /arch:AVX512, /arch:IA32)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.EnhancedInstructionSet.Disable
member.summary: Not Set

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.EnhancedInstructionSet.SIMD
member.summary: Streaming SIMD Extensions. (/arch:SSE)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.EnhancedInstructionSet.SIMD2
member.summary: Streaming SIMD Extensions 2. (/arch:SSE2)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.EnhancedInstructionSet.AdvancedVectorExtensions
member.summary: Advanced Vector Extensions. (/arch:AVX)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.EnhancedInstructionSet.AdvancedVectorExtensions2
member.summary: Advanced Vector Extensions 2. (/arch:AVX2)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.EnhancedInstructionSet.AdvancedVectorExtensions512
member.summary: Advanced Vector Extensions 512. (/arch:AVX512)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.EnhancedInstructionSet.NoEnhancedInstructions
member.summary: No Enhanced Instructions. (/arch:IA32)

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FloatingPointModel
member.summary: Floating Point Model
member.remarks: Sets the floating point model.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FloatingPointModel.Precise
member.summary: Improves the consistency of floating-point tests for equality and inequality.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FloatingPointModel.Strict
member.summary: The strictest floating-point model. /fp:strict causes fp_contract to be OFF and fenv_access to be ON. /fp:except is implied and can be disabled by explicitly specifying /fp:except-. When used with /fp:except-, /fp:strict enforces strict floating-point semantics but without respect for exceptional events.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FloatingPointModel.Fast
member.summary: Creates the fastest code in the majority of cases.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.FloatingPointExceptions
member.summary: Enable Floating Point Exceptions
member.remarks: Reliable floating-point exception model. Exceptions will be raised immediately after they are triggered.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CreateHotPatchableCode
member.summary: Create Hotpatchable Image
member.remarks: When hotpatching is on, the compiler ensures that first instruction of each function is two bytes, which is required for hot patching.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.ConformanceMode
member.summary: Conformance mode
member.remarks: Enables or suppresses conformance mode. (/permissive-, /permissive).

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.ConformanceMode.Disable
member.summary: No

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.ConformanceMode.Enable
member.summary: Yes

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.DisableLanguageExtensions
member.summary: Disable Language Extensions
member.remarks: Suppresses or enables language extensions.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RemoveUnreferencedCodeData
member.summary: Remove unreferenced code and data
member.remarks: When specified, compiler no longer generates symbol information for unreferenced code and data.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.BuiltInWChartType
member.summary: Treat WChar_t As Built in Type
member.remarks: When specified, the type wchar_t becomes a native type that maps to __wchar_t in the same way that short maps to __int16. /Zc:wchar_t is on by default.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.ForceLoopScope
member.summary: Force Conformance in For Loop Scope
member.remarks: Used to implement standard C++ behavior for the for statement loops with Microsoft extensions (/Za, /Ze (Disable Language Extensions)). /Zc:forScope is on by default.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.RTTI
member.summary: Enable Run-Time Type Information
member.remarks: Adds code for checking C++ object types at run time (runtime type information).

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CallingConvention
member.summary: Calling Convention
member.remarks: Select the default calling convention for your application (can be overridden by function).

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CallingConvention.cdecl
member.summary: __cdecl
member.remarks: Specifies the __cdecl calling convention for all functions except C++ member functions and functions marked __stdcall or __fastcall.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CallingConvention.fastcall
member.summary: __fastcall
member.remarks: Specifies the __fastcall calling convention for all functions except C++ member sfunctions and functions marked __cdecl or __stdcall. All __fastcall functions must have prototypes.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CallingConvention.stdcall
member.summary: __stdcall
member.remarks: Specifies the __stdcall calling convention for all functions except C++ member functions and functions marked __cdecl or __fastcall. All __stdcall functions must have prototypes.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CallingConvention.vectorcall
member.summary: __vectorcall
member.remarks: Specifies the __vectorcall calling convention for all functions except C++ member functions and functions marked __cdecl, __fastcall, or __stdcall. All __vectorcall functions must have prototypes.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CompileAsWinRT
member.summary: Consume Windows Runtime Extension
member.remarks: Consume the Windows Run Time languages extensions.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.ShowIncludes
member.summary: Show Includes
member.remarks: Generates a list of include files with compiler output.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CppLanguageStandard
member.summary: C++ Language Standard
member.remarks: Determines the C++ language standard the compiler will enforce. It is recommended to use the latest version when possible. (/std:c++14, /std:c++17, /std:c++20, /std:c++latest)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CppLanguageStandard.CPP14
member.summary: ISO C++14 Standard

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CppLanguageStandard.CPP17
member.summary: ISO C++17 Standard

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CppLanguageStandard.CPP20
member.summary: ISO C++20 Standard

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CppLanguageStandard.Latest
member.summary: Preview - Features from the Latest C++ Working Draft

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CLanguageStandard
member.summary: C Language Standard
member.remarks: Determines the C language standard the compiler will enforce. It is recommended to use the latest version when possible.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CLanguageStandard.Legacy
member.summary: Default (Legacy MSVC)

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Options.Vc.Compiler.CLanguageStandard.C11
member.summary: ISO C11 Standard

member.name: T:Sharpmake.PlatformRegistry
member.summary: Global registry that maps platform-specific implementations of interfaces with a concrete implementation. This facility allows to add and remove platform-specific generators without having to break any code.
member.remarks: This class searches for implementations using .NET reflection when the type is loaded by looking for types marked with in assemblies marked with . It may also store default implementations to fall-back to when it does not find any implementation for a requested platform and interface. Default implementations must be marked with .

member.name: T:Sharpmake.DependencySetting
member.summary: Options to specify the properties of the dependencies between projects. This is used with and .

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.OnlyBuildOrder
member.summary: The dependent project must be built after the dependency. Otherwise the two files have no dependencies.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.LibraryFiles
member.summary: The dependent project inherits the library files of the dependency. Valid only when the project is a C or a C++ project.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.LibraryPaths
member.summary: The dependent project inherits the library paths of the dependency. Valid only when the project is a C or a C++ project.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.IncludePaths
member.summary: The dependent project inherits the include paths of the dependency. Valid only when the project is a C or a C++ project.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.Defines
member.summary: The dependent project inherits the defined symbols of the dependency. Valid only when the project is a C or a C++ project.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.AdditionalUsingDirectories
member.summary: The dependent project inherits the `using` paths of the dependency. Valid only if the project is a C# project and uses Microsoft C++/CX extensions .

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.Default
member.summary: Specifies that the dependent project inherits the dependency's library files, library paths, include paths and defined symbols.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencySetting.DefaultWithoutLinking
member.summary: Specifies that the dependent project inherits the dependency's include paths and defined symbols, but not it's library files or library paths. Use this for header-only C++ libraries.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.DependencyType
member.summary: Visibility types for inter-project dependency relationships. This setting is usually only meaningful in cases where a library depends on another library because one of its executables has an end-point in the other's dependency graph.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencyType.Private
member.summary: Specifies that the dependency relationship is private. The dependent project will not expose the dependency's exported properties, such as it's include paths.
member.remarks: A library that has a private dependency relationship with another library will use that library internally when compiled but will not expose the private dependency's exported properties (library paths, include paths, etc.) when other projects link to it. For example, if library B has a private dependency on C and A wants to link to B, A will not inherit any of C's include paths, library paths, etc.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.DependencyType.Public
member.summary: Specifies that the dependency relationship is public. The dependent project will expose the dependency's exported properties as it's own.
member.remarks: A library that has a public dependency relationship with another library will expose that dependency's include paths, library paths, etc. to any project that has a public dependency on it. For example, if library B has a public dependency on C and A wants to link to B, A will inherit all of C's include paths, library paths, etc.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.IConfigurationTasks
member.summary: Interface for classes that implement platform-specific tasks for generating configurations. An implementation of this interface is required when generating for a platform.
member.remarks: Implementations can assume that they will only be called by Sharpmake, and that the arguments are sane (ex: is passed valid (non-null) configurations).

member.name: M:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.IConfigurationTasks.SetupDynamicLibraryPaths(Sharpmake.Project.Configuration,Sharpmake.DependencySetting,Sharpmake.Project.Configuration)
member.summary: Sets up the library paths when adding a dependency on a dynamic library.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.ExecuteTargetCopy
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to copy output files to the output directory.
member.remarks:
This setting is provided for libraries, because they are usually intermediate artifacts during the compilation process and do not need to be in the final output directory unless it's necessary.
The default is false. Setting this to true will force the generators to copy the library artifacts.
If is set to a value that corresponds to an executable program (ie: ), the generators disregard this property and always copy the results.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.AllowOutputDllCopy
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the configuration output dll file will be copied in the target path of the projects depending on it.
member.remarks:
This setting only apply with This setting is usefull for dlls that are dynamically loaded: The dll do not need to be put along the executable.
The default is true. Setting this to false will prevent the generators to copy the library artifact in the exe directory.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CopyLinkerPdbToDependentTargets

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CopyCompilerPdbToDependentTargets

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.ExportAdditionalLibrariesEvenForStaticLib
member.summary: Setting this boolean to true forces Sharpmake to fill in the AD fields in the current static library project.
member.remarks:
Since Sharpmake handles all dependencies, using an AdditionalDependencies field in your project is typically useless for static libraries. However, when dependents aren't generated by Sharpmake, (that is, when a .sln contains Sharpmake generated projects as static libraries as well as manually maintained dependent projects) this feature can be useful.
The default is false. Set this boolean to true to make Sharpmake fill in the fields for the current static library project.

Ignored unless generating for Visual Studio This property allows to get the same project being in different folder dependeng on the solution name. Ex. member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.LinkerPdbSuffix
member.summary: Gets or sets the suffix to use in . If unset, the pdb file names will be the target name with a suffix and the .pdb extension.
member.remarks: Always put a separate pdb for the compiler in the intermediate path to avoid conflicts with the one from the linker. This helps the following things: 1. Makes the linker go faster 2. Avoid pdbs for dlls and .exe(s) growing and growing at each link 3. Makes incremental linking work better.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.LinkerPdbFilePath
member.summary: Gets or sets the directory and file name of the Visual Studio *linker* PDB file, including the file extension.
member.remarks:
Used only when generating a Visual Studio project.
The default value is: [conf.TargetPath]/[conf.TargetFileFullName][conf.LinkerPdbSuffix].pdb.
Always put a separate PDB for the compiler in the intermediate path to avoid conflicts with the one from the linker.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CompilerPdbSuffix
member.summary: Gets or sets the suffix to use in .
member.remarks: Provided only as a convenience as it is only used in the default value of to assign a suffix to the PDB. If you change so that it doesn't use this property, then it isn't used.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CompilerPdbFilePath
member.summary: Gets or sets the directory and file name of the Visual Studio compiler PDB file, including the file extension.
member.remarks:
Used only when generating a Visual Studio project.
The default value is [conf.IntermediatePath]/[conf.TargetFileFullName][conf.CompilerPdbSuffix].pdb.
The default file name in in Sharpmake does not match its default file name in Visual Studio for compiler PDB, which is VCx0.pdb. See /Fd (Program Database File Name) https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/9wst99a9.aspx . If you mean to use Visual Studio's default value, you must set this property to null.
Always put a separate PDB for the compiler in the intermediate path to avoid conflicts with the one from the linker.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.AdditionalCompilerOptions
member.summary: Gets a list of compiler options to send when calling the compiler.
member.remarks:
Generators are allowed to transform the textual representation of the options added here so that they work with the shell of the operating system or with the makefile format.
The values in this list are simply concatenated, separated with spaces, sanitized for the shell, and then appended directly to the command that calls the compiler.
They are not translated from one compiler to the other. When you use this property, you need to know which C++ compiler you're using.
This property is for the compiler. Its counterpart for the linker is .

Both and must be null if the project doesn't have precompiled headers.
Sharpmake assumes that a relative path here is relative to . If that isn't correct, you must use an absolute path.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.PrecompHeader
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the precompiled header in C and C++ projects, ie: stdafx.h. This property must be null for projects that do not have a precompiled header.
member.remarks:
Both and must be null if the project doesn't have precompiled headers.
Sharpmake assumes that any relative path entered here is relative to . If that isn't correct, you must use an absolute path.
The source files must manually include this header or you will have compiler errors. Sharpmake merely tells the compiler to expect a precompiled header. The compiler doesn't implicitly include the header.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData
member.summary: This is all the data specific to a custom build step. The ones stored in the project configuration use absolute paths but we need relative paths when we're ready to export a specific project file.

member.name: T:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData.ProjectFilter
member.summary: This lets us filter which type of project files should have this custom build step. This is specifically used to deal with the limitations of different build systems.
member.remarks:
Visual studio only supports one build action per file, so if you need both compilation and some other build steps such as QT or Documentation generation on the same file, you need to put the rule on a different input file that also depends on the real input file.
FASTBuild is key based, not file based. So it can have two different operations on the same file. If you need support for FASTBuild, you can make two different custom build rules with one specific to BFF and the other excluding BFF.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData.ProjectFilter.AllProjects
member.summary: The custom build step is used for both project file and FASTBuild generation.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData.ProjectFilter.ExcludeBFF
member.summary: The custom build step excludes BFF.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData.ProjectFilter.BFFOnly
member.summary: The custom build step is specific to BFF

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData.KeyInput
member.summary: File custom builds are bound to a specific existing file. They run when the file is changed.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData.Executable
member.summary: This is the executable for the custom build step.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData.ExecutableArguments
member.summary: These are the arguments to pass to the executable.
member.remarks: We support [input] and [output] tags in the executable arguments that will auto-resolve to the relative paths to and .

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData.Description
member.summary: This is what will appear in the project file under "description". It's also the key used for FASTBuild, so it should be unique per build step if you want to use FASTBuild.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.CustomFileBuildStepData.Output
member.summary: For FASTBuild compatibility, we can only have one input and one output per custom command. This is what we tell the build system we're going to produce.

member.summary: Specifies whether this step should run in builds for project files or FASTBuild or both.

member.name: F:Sharpmake.Project.Configuration.StartWorkingDirectory
member.summary: Gets or sets the working directory when a C# project is started from Visual Studio.

members.member:
Defines where the compiler will generate an XML documentation file at compile time.
The compiler generated XML file can be distributed alongside your .NET assembly so that Visual Studio and other IDEs can use IntelliSense to show quick information about types or members. Additionally, the XML file can be run through tools like DocFX and Sandcastle to generate API reference websites
The following will output an XML file in the target directory with the same root filename as the assembly
conf.XmlDocumentationFile = @"[conf.TargetPath]\[project.AssemblyName].xml";
C# only

member.name: T:Sharpmake.OrderableStrings
member.summary: Same as Strings but support to specify additionally an order number for every entry. Every entry has by default the value 0. Putting negative values will result in the entries to be first after a sort, putting positive will result in the entries to be last after a sort. Order numbers are kept when copying container to another OrderableStrings. It is forbidden to specify 2 different non-zero order numbers for the exact same string in 2 merged together OrderableStrings.
